;Two spain scientists passed through neurological and optical analysis, then made a new interpretation of Mona Lisa's enigmatic smile. Autumnâ€™s Most Terrific ;http://www.myafclothing.com/">;abercrombie; and fitch; Tendency Their latest study suggests that Mona Lisa Smile results from the visual errors. The reason for the appearance and disappearance of her smile is when we are watching her, our eyes convey different information to our brain.Come to Buy Sterling ;http://www.myafclothing.com/">;abercrombie; and fitch; ! They Are Now at the Most Competitive Price!

;
;

;"Mona Lisa", created by the famous Italian painter Leonardo da Vinci, is the most prestigious portrait in the world. Hey! Stop Damage Your Impeccable ;http://www.tiffanystore.org/">;tiffany; jewellery; And the charming smile of the Mona Lisa is a dream-like miracle through ages, which is called the mysterious smile by art historians. Why she was radiant just now and suddenly turns to look so serious? Her enigmatic smile makes many admirers and researchers puzzled and confused.

;
;

;The scientists Louis Martinez Outlaw and Diego Alonso Pablos from Alicante Academy of Neurology of Spain made a deep research into that. In their view, different cells of the retina convey different categories of information or "channels" to the brain. These channels will encoded the objects, size, clarity, brightness and location of visual range. Outlaw said, "Sometimes a channel will be covered by another channel and then the smile can be seen, sometimes the channels will be dominated by other channels, and then no smile can be seen."

;
;

;To analyse visional smile of Mona Lisa at large, Martinez Outlaw and Alonso Pabulusi made volunteers stand different position and angle to appreciate Mona Lisa and recorded their smile change to study different visual channels.

;
;

;At first, they asked the volunteers to see the picture in the different distance, but it was difficult for the volunteers to distinguish her facial expression from the far distance as a result of tiny picture. And with the approaching to the portrait, the picture became larger and the subjects saw the smile-the bigger the portrait was, the easier the smile was seen. This suggests that the central vision cells are able to carry out the information of smile as well as the peripheral vision cells are.

;
;

;Then they made a contrast study about light to make sure whether light will affect Mona Lisa's smile or not. Two kinds of cells determine the brightness of objects in the environment. One is called "concentrating cells". This kind of cells can be stimulated only when the center of the object is bright, and it`s this kind of cells that let us see the stars in the night sky. The other one is "scattered cells", which is only activated when the center of the object is dark. It is them that make us identify the letters in the textbook.

;
;

;Martinez Outlaw asked the volunteers to stare at the white screen and the black screen for 30 seconds respectively, and then let them watch the Mona Lisa portrait. Volunteers after watching a white screen are easier to see the Mona Lisa smile. It is because the white screen reduced the "scattered cells". Therefore, Outlaw came to a conclusion that "concentrating cells" could perceive the Mona Lisa smile. This is of course not all the conclusions of the study because the volunteers' eyes can not help but move to her left cheek right after they distinguished her smile. This indicates that peripheral vision was also involved.

;
;

;Could it be that that da Vinci tried to increase the trouble to the admirers instead of providing the muse for scientists? Outlaw said, "It was absolutely sure. He had written in his note, he would print the expression with extensive changes which were just all mortal beings in his eye."

;
;

;That was not the first time for scientists to unscramble the masterpieces of Leonardo da Vinci. In 1993, the Canadian art historian Susan Giroux revealed shocking research findings that Mona Lisa's lips which have enchanted numerous lookers should be the back of a naked guy. American Maryland Dr. Joseph - Bao Stokowski said, "Mona Lisa does not fundamentally smile, and her facial expression clearly shows that she wants to cover the fact that she does not grow front teeth." Dr. Jean-Jacques Kongdaite, a brain surgery expert, believed that Mona Lisa had suffered a stroke before long, which made the muscles of her half face loosed with wry mouth which seemed that she was smiling. In 2005, a U.S. research team said that the interference factors between the path of the retina and the visual cortex will determine what we see either a smile or other expressions.

;
